title: Using dropout
text: Survey data often encounters challenge dropout – instances participants fail complete sections survey due interruptions omissions. Handling dropouts effectively crucial accurate data analysis interpretation. dropout package provides solution offering insights participant behavior survey process.

title: Using dropout
text: Let’s embark deeper exploration dropout package delving drop_summary function. function serves pivotal tool gaining -depth insights dropout patterns within dataset. effectively utilize drop_summary function, specify last column dataset corresponds survey items. encounter warning message using function, attributed either following reasons: dataset contains instances dropout. Additional columns beyond survey items exist, aren’t correctly identified . example, “flying” dataset, final survey-related item stored “location_census_region” column. Following , “survey_type” column contains supplementary survey information. Many datasets incorporate similar non-survey-related data, ’s crucial consider cases. last column left unspecified, drop_summary function assume survey-related items present. gain comprehensive overview dropout patterns within dataset, consider following code snippet: Now, let’s delve intricacies drop_summary function valuable insights provides structured format.
code: drop_summary(flying, "location_census_region") #> # A tibble: 27 × 8 #>    column_name           dropout drop_rate drop_na section_na single_na missing #>    <chr>                   <int>     <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1 respondent_id               0      0          0          0         0       0 #>  2 travel_frequency            0      0          0          0         0       0 #>  3 seat_recline               18      0.02      18        164         0     182 #>  4 height                      0      0.02      18        164        12     194 #>  5 children_under_18           1      0.02      19        164         6     189 #>  6 two_armrests                1      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  7 middle_armrest              0      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  8 window_shade                0      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  9 moving_to_unsold_seat       1      0.02      21        164         0     185 #> 10 talking_to_seatmate         0      0.02      21        164         0     185 #> # ℹ 17 more rows #> # ℹ 1 more variable: completion_rate <dbl>

title: Using dropout
text: use drop_summary function, output receive compact yet informative summary, packaged either dataframe tibble. summary consists multiple columns, provides insights different dimensions dropout analysis within dataset.

title: Using dropout
text: column_name: Lists names columns dataset analyzed dropouts. dropout: Contains frequency dropouts within listed column, allowing see dropout rates might significant. drop_rate: Shows overall percentage dropout incidents column. useful understanding relative impact dropouts various parts dataset. drop_na: Provides percentage missing values column can attributed specifically dropouts. offers insights nature missing data. section_na: Indicates occurrences missing values span least n consecutive columns (n defaults 3). can adjust parameter using section_min shown : column particularly useful identifying participants might skip entire sections survey without dropping completely. single_na: Reveals percentage single-instance missing values column, associated systematic dropouts section skips. completion_rate: Denotes overall data completion rate analyzed column, enabling gauge integrity reliability dataset.
code: drop_summary(data, last_col, section_min = n)

title: Using dropout
text: One core tools dropout package drop_detect function. function serves comprehensive tool isolating understanding individual participant dropout behaviors. Specifically, reveals whether participant left survey prematurely pinpoints exact juncture dropout took place. structure usage drop_detect intentionally made resonate drop_summary function, ensuring consistency ease adoption.

title: Using dropout
text: dropout: Boolean column (TRUE FALSE). TRUE value signifies respective participant exited survey prematurely. dropout_column: marked TRUE dropout column, field specifies exact column question triggered dropout. dropout_index: Offers direct reference row number dropout incident occurred, facilitating easier traceability.

title: Using dropout
text: practical insights, consider applying drop_detect ‘flying’ dataset. ’s can achieve : Moreover, wish append extracted dropout details back original dataset, can employ bind_cols function dplyr package: integration dropout specifics primary dataset can act preliminary step nuanced analyses, like zoning specific dropout triggers, assessing commonalities among dropouts, relevant exploratory exercises. Subsequent sections delve exemplified applications integrated approach.
code: drop_detect(flying, "location_census_region") drop_detect(flying, "location_census_region") %>%    bind_cols(flying, .)

title: Using dropout
text: drop_detect function can useful identifying filtering early dropouts, .e., participants stopped answering survey specific column. example, can filter participants drop early, ‘late’ dropout demographic part questions, using dropout_index:
code: flying %>%    drop_detect("location_census_region") %>%    bind_cols(flying, .) %>%    filter(dropout == FALSE | dropout_index > 22)

title: Using dropout
text: ’re interested specific section questions want filter dropouts section_na, two approaches:

previous_headings: Practical Workflow Examples > Analyzing Specific Sections
title: Using dropout
text: approach, create subset data containing first 22 columns. apply drop_detect function subset identify dropouts relevant indicators:
code: flying %>%    select(1:22) %>%   drop_detect() %>%    bind_cols(flying, .) %>%    filter(dropout == FALSE)

previous_headings: Practical Workflow Examples > Analyzing Specific Sections
title: Using dropout
text: can specify last_col parameter last question section, identify dropouts point:
code: flying %>%    drop_detect("smoking_violation") %>%    bind_cols(flying, .) %>%    filter(dropout == FALSE)

title: Using dropout
text: One practical application compare demographics (e.g., age gender) left section . following code generates bar graph breaks dropout rates age group gender. Comparative Analysis Age Gender Dropout Rates visualizing data, can easily discern patterns disparities among different demographic groups respect dropout rates.
code: library(ggplot2)  flying %>%   drop_detect("smoking_violation") %>%    bind_cols(flying, .) %>%    filter(!is.na(gender)) %>%    mutate(age = factor(age, levels = c("18-29", "30-44", "45-60", "> 60"))) %>%    ggplot(aes(x=age, fill=dropout)) +   geom_bar(position="dodge") +   facet_grid(gender ~ .) +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1))

what: Exploring Relationships: Dropout, Age and Gender
title: Using dropout
text: Another interesting avenue explore whether ’s relationship dropout behavior (case leaving section) demographic variables like age gender: can particularly useful hypothesis testing can aid uncovering patterns data.
code: test <- flying %>%   drop_detect("smoking_violation") %>%    bind_cols(flying, .) %>%    filter(!is.na(gender)) %>%   select(dropout, age, gender) %>%    mutate(dropout = as.numeric(ifelse(dropout == TRUE, 1, 0)))  glm_model <- glm(dropout ~ gender + age, data = test, family = binomial) print(summary(glm_model))

what: tools for dropout analysis when working with survey data
title: tools for dropout analysis when working with survey data
text: dropout package offers robust tools dropout analysis survey data. helps identify handle incomplete responses effectively ensure quality research findings.

title: tools for dropout analysis when working with survey data
text: can install development version dropout GitHub using following command:
code: devtools::install_github("hendr1km/dropout")

title: tools for dropout analysis when working with survey data
text: drop_detect: Detects participants drop survey recognizing NA sequences last question survey. Additionally, function provides column name index dropout occurs. dropout_summary: Offers high-level summary dropout occurrences, providing key statistics understand patterns participant dropouts across different survey questions.

title: tools for dropout analysis when working with survey data
code: library(dropout) library(dplyr) # not necessary, but recommended  # Detect dropouts in the 'flying' dataset up to the column "location_census_region" drop_detect(flying, "location_census_region") %>%   bind_cols(flying, .) %>%   filter(dropout == FALSE | dropout_index > 22)

title: tools for dropout analysis when working with survey data
code: library(dropout)  # Summarizing dropouts in the 'flying' dataset up to the column "location_census_region" dropout_summary(flying, "location_census_region")

title: Detecting Dropouts in Surveys — drop_detect
text: drop_detect function detects participants dropped survey. identifies sequences NA values last survey question pinpoints column dropout occurred. also provides index column, enabling targeted analysis dropout patterns.

title: Detecting Dropouts in Surveys — drop_detect
code: drop_detect(data, last_col = NULL)

title: Detecting Dropouts in Surveys — drop_detect
text: data dataframe tibble containing survey data. last_col index position column name last survey item. optional used additional columns data frame part survey questions interested .

title: Detecting Dropouts in Surveys — drop_detect
text: dataframe tibble row corresponds row original dataset. contains three columns: dropout: logical indicating whether dropout detected row. dropout_column: dropout TRUE, name column dropout occurred. dropout_index: dropout TRUE, index (column number) dropout occurred.

title: Detecting Dropouts in Surveys — drop_detect
code: # Basic usage drop_detect(flying, "location_census_region") #> # A tibble: 1,040 × 3 #>    dropout_column     dropout dropout_index #>    <chr>              <lgl>           <int> #>  1 seat_recline       TRUE                3 #>  2 NA                 FALSE              NA #>  3 NA                 FALSE              NA #>  4 NA                 FALSE              NA #>  5 NA                 FALSE              NA #>  6 NA                 FALSE              NA #>  7 NA                 FALSE              NA #>  8 NA                 FALSE              NA #>  9 switch_for_friends TRUE               15 #> 10 NA                 FALSE              NA #> # ℹ 1,030 more rows

title: Summarizing Dropouts in Surveys — drop_summary

title: Summarizing Dropouts in Surveys — drop_summary
code: drop_summary(data, last_col, section_min = 3)

title: Summarizing Dropouts in Surveys — drop_summary
text: data dataframe tibble containing survey data. last_col index position column name last survey item. optional used additional columns data frame part survey questions interested . section_min Indicates occurrences missing values span least n consecutive columns (n defaults 3)

title: Summarizing Dropouts in Surveys — drop_summary
text: dataframe tibble containing summary statistics dropouts. Typical columns might include: question_name: name survey question column. dropout_count: number dropouts question. dropout_percentage: percentage participants dropped question.

title: Summarizing Dropouts in Surveys — drop_summary
code: # Basic usage drop_summary(flying, "location_census_region") #> # A tibble: 27 × 8 #>    column_name           dropout drop_rate drop_na section_na single_na missing #>    <chr>                   <int>     <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1 respondent_id               0      0          0          0         0       0 #>  2 travel_frequency            0      0          0          0         0       0 #>  3 seat_recline               18      0.02      18        164         0     182 #>  4 height                      0      0.02      18        164        12     194 #>  5 children_under_18           1      0.02      19        164         6     189 #>  6 two_armrests                1      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  7 middle_armrest              0      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  8 window_shade                0      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  9 moving_to_unsold_seat       1      0.02      21        164         0     185 #> 10 talking_to_seatmate         0      0.02      21        164         0     185 #> # ℹ 17 more rows #> # ℹ 1 more variable: completion_rate <dbl>  # Summarizing dropouts up to a specific column drop_summary(flying, last_col = "age") #> # A tibble: 24 × 8 #>    column_name           dropout drop_rate drop_na section_na single_na missing #>    <chr>                   <int>     <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1 respondent_id               0      0          0          0         0       0 #>  2 travel_frequency            0      0          0          0         0       0 #>  3 seat_recline               18      0.02      18        164         0     182 #>  4 height                      0      0.02      18        164        12     194 #>  5 children_under_18           1      0.02      19        164         6     189 #>  6 two_armrests                1      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  7 middle_armrest              0      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  8 window_shade                0      0.02      20        164         0     184 #>  9 moving_to_unsold_seat       1      0.02      21        164         0     185 #> 10 talking_to_seatmate         0      0.02      21        164         0     185 #> # ℹ 14 more rows #> # ℹ 1 more variable: completion_rate <dbl>  # Read more in the vignette for interpreting summary statistics and plotting dropout trends.

title: Flying Etiquette Survey Data — flying
text: dataframe 1040 obs. 28 columns, : respondent_id respondentid travel_frequency often travel plane? seat_recline ever recline seat fly? height tall ? children_under_18 children 18? two_armrests row three seats, get use two arm rests? middle_armrest row two seats, get use middle arm rest? window_shade control window shade? moving_to_unsold_seat rude move unsold seat plane? talking_to_seatmate generally speaking, rude say words stranger sitting next plane? getting_up_on_6_hour_flight 6 hour flight nyc la, many times acceptable get aisle seat? obligation_to_reclined_seat rude recline seat plane? eliminate_reclining_seats given opportunity, eliminate possibility reclining seats planes entirely? switch_for_friends rude ask someone switch seats order closer friends? switch_for_family rude ask someone switch seats order closer family? wake_passenger_bathroom rude wake passenger trying go bathroom? wake_passenger_walk rude wake passenger trying walk around? baby_on_plane general, rude bring baby plane? unruly_children general, rude knowingly bring unruly children plane? electronics_violation ever used personal electronics take landing violation flight attendant's direction? smoking_violation ever smoked cigarette airplane bathroom rules? gender gender age age household_income household income education education location_census_region location (census region) survey_type type survey
